docs.text:
Python Mini Documentation


Python Mini implements a subset of Python 2, plus the addition of two graphical libraries, Turtle, Processing.


Get started


from random import randint
a = randint()
print a

docs.title: Get started

docs.text:
Turtle graphic library is a subset of the Python Turtle.


Import library


from turtle import Turtle

# Generate Turtle object, name it like your pet
nick = Turtle()




Now you have your own turtle, there are several functions you can use to control your turtle.


Motion


➤ 
turtle.forward(distance)
 or 
turtle.fd(distance)




Move the turtle forward by the specified distance, in the direction the turtle is headed.


https://docs.python.org/2/library/turtle.html#turtle.forward




Example:


# move forward 100 steps
nick.forward(100)
docs.title: Motion

docs.text:
from turtle import Turtle

# Generate Turtle object, name it like your pet
nick = Turtle()  Now you have your own turtle, there are several functions you can use to control your turtle.
docs.title: Import library

docs.text:
➤  turtle.forward(distance)  or  turtle.fd(distance)   Move the turtle forward by the specified distance, in the direction the turtle is headed.  https://docs.python.org/2/library/turtle.html#turtle.forward   Example:  # move forward 100 steps
nick.forward(100)

docs.text:
mouse


Property




mouse.x


mouse.y


mouse.px (?)


mouse.py (?)


mouse.button




Functions




mousePressed


mouseMoved


mouseReleased




Example:


from processing import *

def mousePressed():
    print 
pressed at:
, mouse.x, mouse.y
    # left button is 37, right button is 39
    print 
mouse button:
, mouse.button

def mouseMoved():
    print 
mouse moved


def mouseReleased():
    print 
released ...


run()
